edu.rit.util

Class Instance

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.util.Instance

  • public class Instance
extends java.lang.Object
    Class Instance provides static methods for creating instances of classes.

    • Method Detail

      • newInstance

        public static java.lang.Object newInstance(java.lang.String s)
                                    throws java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                                           java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                           java.lang.InstantiationException,
                                           java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                                           java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of a class as specified by the given string. Calling this method is equivalent to calling newInstance(s,false). See the newInstance(String,boolean) method for further information.
        Parameters:
        s - Constructor expression string.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if s does not obey the required syntax.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown if the given class cannot be found.
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if a suitable constructor cannot be found in the given class.
        java.lang.InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the given constructor.
        java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the given constructor throws an exception.

      • newInstance

        public static java.lang.Object newInstance(java.lang.String s,
                           boolean disableAccessChecks)
                                    throws java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                                           java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                           java.lang.InstantiationException,
                                           java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                                           java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of a class as specified by the given string. The string must consist of a fully-qualified class name, a left parenthesis, zero or more comma-separated values, and a right parenthesis. However, commas inside nested parentheses are part of the current value. No whitespace is allowed.

        The newInstance() method examines all the declared constructors of the class and attempts to match each constructor argument's data type to the corresponding value in the constructor expression, as follows:

        • If the constructor argument is a class type, the value must consist of a (nested) valid constructor expression for that class.

        • If the constructor argument is type int, byte, or short, the value must consist of (case insensitive) an optional sign (+ or -); 0B plus one or more base-2 digits, or 0X plus one or more base-16 digits, or 0 plus zero or more base-8 digits, or 1 through 9 plus zero or more base-10 digits. The value must be in the range of type int. For an argument of type byte or short, the integer value is converted to a byte value or a short value.

        • If the constructor argument is type long, the value must consist of (case insensitive) an optional sign (+ or -); 0B plus one or more base-2 digits, or 0X plus one or more base-16 digits, or 0 plus zero or more base-8 digits, or 1 through 9 plus zero or more base-10 digits; optional L. The value must be in the range of type long.

        • If the constructor argument is type double or float, the value must be as defined in the Double.valueOf() method. For an argument of type float, the double value is converted to a float value.

        • If the constructor argument is type String, the value may be anything.

        • If the final constructor argument is type int[], byte[], or short[], all remaining values must be integers as described above; these values are bundled into an integer array, a byte array, or a short array.

        • If the final constructor argument is type long[], all remaining values must be long integers as described above; these values are bundled into a long integer array.

        • If the final constructor argument is type double[] or float[], all remaining values must be doubles as described above; these values are bundled into a double array or a float array.

        • If the final constructor argument is type String[], all remaining values are bundled into a string array.

        • Constructor arguments of other types are not supported.

        If one constructor that matches the values is found, the newInstance() method invokes that constructor, passing in the provided values, and returns a reference to the newly-created instance.

        If the disableAccessChecks argument is true, access checks are suppressed when constructing the instance. This means the object's class and/or the class's pertinent constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        If no constructor that matches the values is found, or if multiple constructors that match the values are found, the newInstance() method throws a NoSuchMethodException.

        Note: To find the given class, the calling thread's context class loader is used.

        Parameters:
        s - Constructor expression string.
        disableAccessChecks - True to disable access checks, false to perform access checks.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if s does not obey the required syntax.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown if the given class cannot be found.
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if a suitable constructor cannot be found in the given class.
        java.lang.InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • newDefaultInstance

        public static java.lang.Object newDefaultInstance(java.lang.String className)
                                           throws java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                                                  java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                                  java.lang.InstantiationException,
                                                  java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                                                  java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of the class with the given name using the class's default constructor. Calling this method is equivalent to calling newDefaultInstance(className,false). See the newDefaultInstance(String,boolean) method for further information.

        Note: To find the class with the given name, the calling thread's context class loader is used.

        Parameters:
        className - Class name.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown if the class with the given name cannot be found.
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the given class does not have a default constructor.
        java.lang.InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • newDefaultInstance

        public static java.lang.Object newDefaultInstance(java.lang.String className,
                                  boolean disableAccessChecks)
                                           throws java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                                                  java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                                  java.lang.InstantiationException,
                                                  java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                                                  java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of the class with the given name using the class's default constructor.

        If the disableAccessChecks argument is true, access checks are suppressed when constructing the new instance. This means the object's class and/or the class's default constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        Note: To find the class with the given name, the calling thread's context class loader is used.

        Parameters:
        className - Class name.
        disableAccessChecks - True to disable access checks, false to perform access checks.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Thrown if the class with the given name cannot be found.
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the given class does not have a default constructor.
        java.lang.InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • newDefaultInstance

        public static <T> T newDefaultInstance(java.lang.Class<T> c)
                            throws java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                   java.lang.InstantiationException,
                                   java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                                   java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of the given class using the class's default constructor. Calling this method is equivalent to calling newDefaultInstance(c,false). See the newDefaultInstance(Class,boolean) method for further information.
        Type Parameters:
        T - Class's data type.
        Parameters:
        c - Class.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the given class does not have a default constructor.
        java.lang.InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • newDefaultInstance

        public static <T> T newDefaultInstance(java.lang.Class<T> c,
                       boolean disableAccessChecks)
                            throws java.lang.NoSuchMethodException,
                                   java.lang.InstantiationException,
                                   java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                                   java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of the given class using the class's default constructor.

        If the disableAccessChecks argument is true, access checks are suppressed when constructing the new instance. This means the object's class and/or the class's default constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Class's data type.
        Parameters:
        c - Class.
        disableAccessChecks - True to disable access checks, false to perform access checks.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the given class does not have a default constructor.
        java.lang.InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • getDefaultConstructor

        public static java.lang.reflect.Constructor<?> getDefaultConstructor(java.lang.Class<?> c)
                                                              throws java.lang.NoSuchMethodException
        Get the given class's default constructor. Calling this method is equivalent to calling getDefaultConstructor(c,false). See the getDefaultConstructor(Class,boolean) method for further information.
        Parameters:
        c - Class.
        Returns:
        Default (no-argument) constructor for the class.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the class does not have a default constructor.

      • getDefaultConstructor

        public static java.lang.reflect.Constructor<?> getDefaultConstructor(java.lang.Class<?> c,
                                                     boolean disableAccessChecks)
                                                              throws java.lang.NoSuchMethodException
        Get the given class's default constructor.

        If the disableAccessChecks argument is true, access checks are suppressed when constructing an instance using the returned constructor. This means the object's class and/or the class's default constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        Parameters:
        c - Class.
        disableAccessChecks - True to disable access checks, false to perform access checks.
        Returns:
        Default (no-argument) constructor for the class.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the class does not have a default constructor.
